column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=condiments, so that a fine flavour is produced without the undue
#Text= preponderance of either.
#Text=It is only in coarse cooking that the flavour of onions, pepper,
#Text= garlic, nutmeg, and eschalot is permitted to prevail.
#Text=As a general
#Text= rule, salt should be used in moderation.
#Text=Sugar is an improvement in nearly all soups, sauces, and gravies; also
#Text= with stewed vegetables, but of course must be used with discretion.
#Text=Ketchups, Soy, Harvey  '  s sauce, &c., are used too indiscrimately by
#Text= inferior cooks; it is better to leave them to be added at table by
#Text= those who approve of their flavour.
#Text=Any thing that is required to be warmed up a second time, should be
#Text= set in a basin placed in a _bain-marie_, or saucepan, filled with
#Text= boiling water, but which must not be allowed to boil; or the article
#Text= will become hardened and the sauce dried up.
#Text=To remove every particle of fat from the gravies of stews, &c., a
#Text=SWEET SAUCE.
#Text=The usual way of making sauces for puddings, is by adding sugar
#Text= to melted butter, or thin egg sauce, flavoring it with white wine,
#Text= brandy, lemon peel, or any other flavor approved of
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MELTED BUTTER.
#Text=Although this sauce is one of the most simple, it is very rarely that
#Text= it is well made.
#Text=Mix with four ounces of butter, a desert spoonful
#Text= of flour, when well mixed, add three table spoonsful of water, put it
#Text= into a clean saucepan kept for the purpose, and stir it carefully
#Text= one way till it boils; white sauce to throw over vegetables served on
#Text= toast, is made in the same way, only putting milk and water, instead
#Text= of water only
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text=SAUCE WITHOUT BUTTER FOR BOILED PUDDINGS.
#Text=Mix a table-spoonful of flour, with two of water, add a little wine,
#Text= lemon peel grated, a small bit of clarified suet, of the size of a
#Text= walnut, grated nutmeg, and sugar, put on in a saucepan, stirring one
#Text= way, and adding water if too thick, lemon juice, or essence of noyeau,
#Text= or almonds may be substituted to vary the flavour
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= SAUCE ROBERT FOR STEAKS.
#Text=Chop up some onions, throw them into a saucepan with a bit of
#Text= clarified fat, let them fry till brown, then add pepper, salt, a
#Text= little gravy, mustard, lemon juice, and vinegar; boil it all, and pour
#Text= over the steaks
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= CAPER SAUCE.
#Text=This is merely melted butter with a few pickled capers simmered in it,
#Text= or they may be put into a sauce made of broth thickened with egg, and
#Text= a little flour
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= SAVORY HERB POWDER.
#Text=It is useful to select a variety of herbs, so that they may always
#Text= be at hand for use: the following are considered to be an excellent
#Text= selection, parsley, savory, thyme, sweet majoram, shalot, chervil, and
#Text= sage, in equal quantities; dry these in the oven, pound them finely
#Text= and keep them in bottles well stopped
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= SEASONING FOR DUCKS AND GEESE.
#Text=Mix chopped onion with an equal quantity of chopped sage, three times
#Text=tisoles, fritters, and stuffings for poultry and veal, it is a branch
#Text= of cooking which requires great care and judgment, the proportions
#Text= should be so blended as to produce a delicate, yet savoury flavor,
#Text= without allowing any particular herb or spice to predominate.
#Text=The ingredients should always be pounded well together in a mortar,
#Text= not merely chopped and moistened with egg, as is usually done by
#Text= inexperienced cooks; forcemeat can be served in a variety of forms,
#Text= and is so useful a resource, that it well repays the attention it
#Text= requires
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= A SUPERIOR FORCEMEAT FOR RISOLLES, FRITTERS, AND SAVORY MEAT BALLS.
#Text=Scrape half a pound of the fat of smoked beef, and a pound of lean
#Text= veal, free from skin, vein, or sinew, pound it finely in a mortar
#Text= with chopped mushrooms, a little minced parsley, salt and pepper,
#Text= and grated lemon peel, then have ready the crumb of two French rolls
#Text= soaked in good gravy, press out the moisture, and add the crumb to the
#Text=meat with three beaten eggs; if the forcemeat is required to be very
#Text= highly flavored, the gravy in which the rolls are soaked should be
#Text= seasoned with mushroom powder; a spoonful of ketchup, a bay leaf, an
#Text= onion, pepper, salt, and lemon juice, add this panada to the pounded
#Text= meat and eggs, form the mixture into any form required, and either fry
#Text= or warm in gravy, according to the dish for which it is intended.
#Text=Any cold meats pounded, seasoned, and made according to the above
#Text= method are excellent; the seasoning can be varied, or rendered simpler
#Text= if required
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= COMMON VEAL, STUFFING.
#Text=Have equal quantities of finely shred suet and grated crumbs of bread,
#Text= add chopped sweet herbs, grated lemon peel, pepper, and salt, pound it
#Text= in a mortar; this is also used for white poultry, with the addition
#Text= of a little grated smoked beef, or a piece of the root of a tongue
#Text= pounded and mixed with the above ingredients.
#Text=SMOKED BEEF.
#Text=As there are seldom conveniences in private kitchens for smoking
#Text= meats, it will generally be the best and cheapest plan to have them
#Text= ready prepared for cooking.
#Text=All kinds of meats smoked and salted,
#Text= are to be met with in great perfection at all the Hebrew butchers.
#Text=_Chorisa_, that most refined and savoury of all sausages, is to be
#Text= also procured at the same places.
#Text=It is not only excellent fried in
#Text= slices with poached eggs or stewed with rice, but imparts a delicious
#Text= flavor to stews, soups, and sauces, and is one of the most useful
#Text= resources of the Jewish kitchen
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= A WHITE FRICANDEAU OF VEAL.
#Text=Take four or five pounds of breast of veal, or fillet from the
#Text= shoulder; stuff it with a finely flavoured veal stuffing and put it
#Text= into a stewpan with water sufficient to cover it, a calf  '  s-foot cut
#Text=in pieces is sometimes added, season with one onion, a blade of mace,
#Text= white pepper and salt, and a sprig of parsley, stew the whole gently
#Text= until the meat is quite tender, then skim and strain the gravy and
#Text= stir in the beaten yolks of four eggs, and the juice of two lemons
#Text= previously mixed smoothly with a portion of the gravy, button
#Text= mushrooms, or pieces of celery stewed with the veal are sometimes
#Text= added by way of varying the flavor, egg and forcemeat balls garnish
#Text= the dish.
#Text=When required to look elegant it should be piqué
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= A BROWN FRICASSEE.
#Text=Cut a breast of veal in pieces, fry them lightly and put them into a
#Text= stewpan with a good beef gravy, seasoned with white pepper, salt, a
#Text= couple of sliced onions (previously browned in a little oil), and a
#Text= piece of whole ginger, let it simmer very slowly for two hours taking
#Text= care to remove the scum or fat, have ready some rich forcemeat and
#Text= spread it about an inch thick over three cold hard boiled eggs, fry
#Text= these for a few moments and put them in the saucepan with the veal;
#Text=Take the fillet off a small leg or shoulder of mutton, rub it well
#Text= over with egg and seasoning, and partly roast it, then place it in a
#Text= stewpan with a little strong gravy, and stew gently till thoroughly
#Text= done; this dish is simple, but exceedingly nice; a few balls or
#Text= fritters to garnish will improve it
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MAINTENON CUTLETS.
#Text=This is merely broiling or frying cutlets in a greased paper, after
#Text= having spread on them a seasoning prepared as follows: make a paste
#Text= of bread crumbs, chopped parsley, nutmeg, pepper, salt, grated lemon
#Text= peel, and thyme, with a couple of beaten eggs; a piquante sauce should
#Text= be served in a tureen
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= A HARRICOT.
#Text=Cut off the best end of a neck of mutton into chops, flour and partly
#Text= fry them, then lay them in a stewpan with carrots, sliced turnips cut
#Text= in small round balls, some button onions, and cover with water; skim
#Text= frequently, season with pepper and salt to taste, color the gravy with
#Text= a little browning and a spoonful of mushroom powder
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= IRISH STEW.
#Text=Is the same as above, excepting that the meat is not previously fried,
#Text= and that potatoes are used instead of turnips and carrots
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MUTTON A L  '  HISPANIOLA.
#Text=Take a small piece of mutton, either part of a shoulder or a fillet
#Text= of the leg, partly roast it, then put it in a stewpan with beef gravy
#Text= enough to cover it, previously seasoned with herbs, a carrot and
#Text=turnip; cut in quarters three large Spanish onions, and place in the
#Text= stewpan round the meat; a stuffing will improve it, and care must be
#Text= taken to free the gravy from every particle of fat
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MUTTON COLLOPS.
#Text=Take from a fine knuckle a couple of slices, cut and trim them in
#Text= collops the size of a tea cup, flatten them and spread over each side
#Text= a forcemeat for cutlets, and fry them; potatoe or Jerusalem artichokes
#Text= cut in slices of the same size and thickness, or pieces of bread
#Text= cut with a fluted cutter, prepared as the collops and fried, must be
#Text= placed alternately in the dish with them; they may be served with a
#Text= pure simple gravy, or very hot and dry on a napkin, garnished with
#Text= fried parsley and slices of lemon.
#Text=The knuckle may be used in the following manner: put it on with
#Text= sufficient water to cover it, season it and simmer till thoroughly
#Text= done, thicken the gravy with prepared barley, and flavor it with lemon
#Text=See blankette of veal
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= TO STEW DUCK WITH GREEN PEAS.
#Text=Stuff and half roast a duck, then put it into a stew-pan with an onion
#Text= sliced, a little mint and about one pint of beef gravy, add after it
#Text= has simmered half an hour, a quart of green peas, and simmer another
#Text= half hour; a little lump sugar is requisite
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= TO WARM COLD POULTRY.
#Text=Cut up the pieces required to be dressed, spread over them a seasoning
#Text= as for cutlets, and fry them; pour over a little good gravy, and
#Text= garnish with sippets of toast and sliced lemon, or place them in an
#Text= edging of rice or mashed potatoes
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= BROILED FOWL AND MUSHROOMS.
#Text=Truss a fine fowl as if for boiling, split it down the back, and broil
#Text= gently; when nearly done, put it in a stewpan with a good gravy, add
#Text= a pint of fresh button mushrooms, season to taste; a little mushroom
#Text= powder and lemon juice improve the flavour
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= PIGEONS.
#Text=To have a good appearance they should be larded and stuffed; glazing
#Text= is also an improvement, they form a nice _entrée_; they may be stewed
#Text= in a strong gravy; when done enough, remove the pigeons, thicken the
#Text= gravy, add a few forcemeat and egg balls, and serve in the dish with
#Text= the pigeons.
#Text=Or they may be split down the back, broiled, and then
#Text= finished in the stew-pan
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= STEWED GIBLETS.
#Text=Scald one or more sets of giblets, set them on the fire with a little
#Text= veal or chicken, or both, in a good gravy; season to taste, thicken
#Text= the gravy, and color it with browning, flavor with mushroom powder
#Text= and lemon-juice and one glass of white wine; forcemeat balls should
#Text= be added a few minutes before serving, and garnish with thin slices of
#Text= hard boiled eggs
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= DUTCH TOAST.
#Text=Take the remains of any cold poultry or meat, mince it and season
#Text= highly; add to it any cold dressed vegetable, mix it up with one or
#Text= more eggs, and let it simmer till hot in a little gravy; have ready
#Text= a square of toast, and serve it on it; squeeze over a little
#Text= lemon-juice, and sprinkle with white pepper.
#Text=Vegetables prepared
#Text=A SAVOURY PIE FOR PERSONS OF DELICATE DIGESTION.
#Text=Cut up fowl and sweetbread, lay in the dish in alternate layers with
#Text= meat, jelly, and the yolks of hard-boiled eggs without the whites,
#Text= and flavor with lemon-juice, white pepper, and salt; cover with rice
#Text= prepared as follows: boil half a pound of rice in sufficient water to
#Text= permit it to swell; when tender beat it up to a thick paste with the
#Text= yolk of one or two eggs, season with a little salt, and spread it over
#Text= the dish thickly.
#Text=The fowl and sweetbread should have been previously
#Text= simmered till half done in a little weak broth; the pie must be baked
#Text= in a gentle oven, and if the rice will not brown sufficiently, finish
#Text= with a salamander
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= DESCAIDES.
#Text=Take the livers of chickens or any other poultry; stew it gently in
#Text= a little good gravy seasoned with a little onion, mushroom essence,
#Text= pepper, and salt; when tender, remove the livers, place them on a
#Text=paste board, and mince them; return them to the saucepan, and stir
#Text= in the yolks of one or two eggs, according to the quantity of liver,
#Text= until the gravy becomes thick; have a round of toast ready on a hot
#Text= plate, and serve it on the toast; this is a very nice luncheon or
#Text= supper dish.
#Text=CHAPTER V.
#Text=Vegetables and Sundries.
#Text=DIRECTIONS FOR CLEANING AND BOILING VEGETABLES.
#Text=Vegetables are extremely nutritious when sufficiently boiled, but are
#Text= unwholesome and indigestible when not thoroughly dressed; still they
#Text= should not be over boiled, or they will lose their flavor.
#Text=Vegetables should be shaken to get out any insects, and laid in water
#Text= with a little salt.
#Text=Soft water is best suited for boiling vegetables, and they require
#Text= plenty of water; a little salt should be put in the saucepan with
#Text= them, and the water should almost invariably be boiling when they are
#Text= put in.
#Text=Potatoes are much better when steamed.
#Text=Peas and several other
#Text= vegetables are also improved by this mode of cooking them, although it
#Text= is seldom adopted in England
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MASHED POTATOES.
#Text=Boil till perfectly tender; let them be quite dry, and press them
#Text= through a cullender, or mash and beat them well with a fork; add a
#Text= piece of butter, and milk, or cream, and continue beating till they
#Text= are perfectly smooth; return them to the saucepan to warm, or they may
#Text=BREAD FRUIT TARTS.
#Text=Line a dish with thin slices of bread, then lay the fruit with brown
#Text= sugar in alternate layers, with slices of bread; when the dish is
#Text= filled, pour over half a tea-cup full of water, and let the top be
#Text= formed of thin pieces of bread thickly strewed over with brown sugar,
#Text= bake until thoroughly done
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= RICE CUSTARD.
#Text=This is a very innocent and nutritive custard.
#Text=Take two ounces of
#Text= whole rice and boil it in three pints of milk until it thickens, then
#Text= add half a pound of pounded sweet almonds, and sweeten to taste; a
#Text= stick of cinnamon and a piece of lemon peel should be boiled in it,
#Text= and then taken out
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text=CREME BRUN.
#Text=Boil a large cup of cream, flavor with essence of almonds and
#Text= cinnamon, and then mix with it the yolk of three eggs, carefully
#Text= beaten and strained, stirring one way to keep it smooth; place it on a
#Text= dish in small heaps, strew over powdered sugar and beaten almonds, and
#Text= brown with a salamander
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= PANCAKES.
#Text=Mix a light batter of eggs with flour and milk or water, fry in
#Text= boiling butter or clarified suet; they may be fried without butter or
#Text= fat, by putting more eggs and a little cream, the pan must be very
#Text= dry and clean; those fried without butter are very delicate and
#Text= fashionable, they should be fried of the very lightest colour; they
#Text= are good also made of rice, which must be boiled in milk till quite
#Text= tender; then beat up with eggs, and flavoured according to taste, and
#Text= fried like other pancakes
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= PANCAKES FOR CHILDREN.
#Text=Take a pint of finely grated bread crumbs, simmer in a little milk
#Text= and water, flavour with cinnamon or lemon peel grated, add a couple of
#Text= beaten eggs, and sweeten to taste, drop a small quantity into the pan
#Text= and fry like pancakes
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= A NICE RICE PUDDING FOR CHILDREN.
#Text=Boil till tender half a pound of well picked rice in one quart of
#Text= fresh milk, sweeten with white sugar, and flavour with whole cinnamon,
#Text= lemon peel, and a bay leaf; when the rice is tender, place it in a
#Text= deep dish, pour over a very little butter warmed in a little milk,
#Text= and bake until brown; a slow oven is requisite unless the rice is
#Text= extremely soft before it is put in the oven
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= PLUM PUDDING.
#Text=To one pound of currants add one pound of raisins, one pound of shred
#Text= suet, one pound flour (or half a pound bread crumbs and half a pound
#Text= of flour), a quarter of a pound of candied orange and lemon peel,
#Text= a little citron cut thin, half a pound of moist sugar; mix all well
#Text= together as each article is added, then stir in six beaten eggs and a
#Text= glass of brandy, beat the pudding well for half an hour, let it stand
#Text= some time, then put it into a basin and boil six or seven hours in
#Text= plenty of water; it should be seasoned according to taste with ginger,
#Text= nutmeg, cloves, &c.
#Text=Serve with sifted sugar or whites of eggs beaten
#Text= to a froth
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= RATAFIA PUDDING.
#Text=Soak the crumb of a French roll and half a pound of ratafia cakes in
#Text= milk or cream, then mix with them three ounces of warmed fresh butter,
#Text= the yolks of five and the whites of two eggs, sweeten to taste; add
#Text= one ounce of pounded almonds, and a few bitter almonds, boil in a
#Text= shape lined with dried cherries, or bake in a cake-tin first well
#Text= buttered, and sprinkled with bread crumbs
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= PASSOVER PUDDING.
#Text=Mix equal quantities of biscuit powder and shred suet, half the
#Text= quantity of currants and raisins, a little spice and sugar, with an
#Text= ounce of candied peels, and fine well beaten eggs; make these into
#Text= a stiff batter, and boil well, and serve with a sweet sauce.
#Text=This
#Text= pudding is excellent baked in a pudding tin, it must be turned out
#Text= when served
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text=and sweeten with white sifted sugar; add grated lemon peel, and a
#Text= spoonful of orange flower-water, and fry of a light brown; the flavor
#Text= may be varied by substituting a few beaten almonds, with one or two
#Text= bitter, instead of the orange flower-water
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= A SUPERIOR RECEIPT FOR PASSOVER FRITTERS.
#Text=Make a thin batter as already described in the former receipt; drop
#Text= it into a souflé pan, fry lightly, and strew over pounded cinnamon,
#Text= sifted sugar, and finely chopped almonds; hold over a salamander to
#Text= brown the upper side.
#Text=Slide the fritter on to a hot dish, and fold;
#Text= pour over, when in the dish, clarified sugar
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= PASSOVER CURRANT FRITTERS.
#Text=Mix a thick batter, as before, add some well-washed and dried
#Text=currants, and fry of a rich brown; serve with a sweet sauce, flavored
#Text= with wine or shrub, and sweetened with moist sugar; these are often
#Text= made in the shape of small balls, and fried and served in the same
#Text= sauce
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= BATTER PUDDING.
#Text=Stir in three ounces of flour, four beaten eggs, and one pint of milk,
#Text= sweeten to taste, and mix to a smooth batter about the thickness of
#Text= good cream, and boil in a buttered basin
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= CUSTARD PUDDING.
#Text=To one desert spoonful of flour, add one pint of fresh milk and the
#Text= yolks of five eggs; flavor according to fancy, with sugar, nutmeg, or
#Text= lemon-peel; beat to a froth two whites of eggs and pour to the rest;
#Text=boil rather more than half an hour
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= BREAD PUDDING.
#Text=Grate stale bread, or soak the crumb of a French roll in milk, which
#Text= must be warmed; beat with it two or three eggs, flavor and sweeten
#Text= to taste, sometimes with a little wine or essence of lemon, or beaten
#Text= almonds; it will require to be boiled about half an hour.
#Text=This pudding
#Text= is excellent made as above, with the addition of the peel of one whole
#Text= lemon grated, with its juice, and baked
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= VERMICELLI AND MACCARONI PUDDING.
#Text=Boil till tender four ounces of either of the above articles, in a
#Text= pint of milk; flavor as directed in the preceding receipt, and boil in
#Text= a mould, which may be lined with raisins.
#Text=It should be served with any
#Text=sweet pudding sauce
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MILLET, ARROWROOT, GROUND RICE, RICE, TAPIOCA, AND SAGO PUDDINGS.
#Text=Puddings of this sort are so similar and simple, that it is only
#Text= necessary to give one receipt, which will serve as a guide for
#Text= all;--they are all made with milk, all require to be thoroughly done,
#Text= all require to be mixed with eggs and sweetened with sugar, and
#Text= are good either boiled or baked.
#Text=The cook must use her judgment in
#Text= adopting the quantities to the size of the pudding required, and the
#Text= taste of the family she serves
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= MINCED MEAT.
#Text=Take one pound of tender roasted meat, two pounds of shred suet, three
#Text= pounds of currants, six chopped apples, a quarter of a loaf grated,
#Text=nutmegs, cloves, pepper, salt, one pound of sugar, grated lemon and
#Text= orange peel, lemon juice, and two wine glasses of brandy, the same of
#Text= white wine, and two ounces of citron, and the same of candied lemon
#Text= peel; mix all well together; the ingredients ought to be added
#Text= separately.
#Text=Minced meat should be kept a day or two before using.
#Text=The
#Text= same proportions, as above, without meat, will be very good; a little
#Text= port wine is sometimes substituted for the brandy
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= BAKED SUET PUDDING.
#Text=Mix one pint of water, six ounces of flour, three of shred suet, and
#Text= two or three beaten eggs; sweeten to taste.
#Text=Add raisins or currants if
#Text= approved, and bake in a brick oven
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= YORKSHIRE PUDDING.
#Text=of dissolved isinglass, beat it all thoroughly together, and fill the
#Text= mould, which should be set in ice till wanted.
#Text=A table spoonful of
#Text= marasquino added to the above, will make _Italian cream_.
#Text=A table
#Text= spoonful of fresh or preserved pine-apple will make _pine-apple
#Text= cream_; this will require the addition of a little lemon syrup.
#Text=A
#Text= table spoonful of ratafia, will make it _ratifia cream_.
#Text=The juice of strawberries or raspberries make fine fruit creams;
#Text= _mille fruit cream_ is made by mixing with the cream any kind of small
#Text= preserved fruit
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= RICE SOUFLES.
#Text=Boil well some fine picked rice, in pure fresh milk, sweeten and
#Text= flavour with a bay leaf, lemon peel, and a stick of cinnamon, all
#Text= which must be taken out when the rice is done, then line with it
#Text= a round dish, or souflé dish, have ready apples previously boiled,
#Text= sweetened, and beat up smoothly, place the apple lightly in the centre
#Text=rather higher in the middle than at the sides, beat up the whites of
#Text= eggs to a froth, sweeten and flavour with lemon, or noyau essence;
#Text= place it in small heaps tastefully on the apple and rice, and brown
#Text= delicately with a salamander.
#Text=This souflé may have stewed cherries or
#Text= any _other_ kind of fruit, instead of the apples if preferred
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= BOILED CUSTARD.
#Text=Take a pint of milk, let it simmer in a very clean saucepan, flavor
#Text= it with lemon-peel and a bay leaf, and sweeten to taste; while gently
#Text= boiling, add the beaten yolks of four eggs, and the whites of two,
#Text= continue stirring until the custard thickens, when it must be removed
#Text= from the fire, but it is requisite to stir it until it cools.
#Text=It is
#Text= necessary to strain the milk before the eggs are added, and also to
#Text= pass the eggs through a sieve.
#Text=Custards are flavoured sometimes
#Text= with essence of almonds; a little cream added to the milk is a great
#Text= improvement.
#Text=The above mixture may be baked in small cups; they
#Text= require a quarter of an hour to bake
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text= CALF  '  S FEET JELLY.
#Text=Boil two feet in two quarts, or five pints of water, till the water
#Text= has half wasted; strain, and when cold, take off the fat, then put it
#Text= in the saucepan with lump sugar, lemon juice, and white wine to taste,
#Text= also a little lemon peel; when simmered a few minutes, throw in the
#Text= whites of two eggs, and their shells broken, which will have the
#Text= effect of clarifying the jelly; let it boil about ten minutes after
#Text= the scum rises, then pour it through a flannel bag or thick cloth,
#Text= dipping the bag or cloth first into hot water; pass the jelly through
#Text= it until clear, then pour it into moulds and put them in a cool place
#Text= to set.
#Text=One calf  '  s foot and one cow heel will be more economical than
#Text= two calfs feet.
#Text=If fruit is desired to be in the jelly, it must be put
#Text= in when the jelly begins to stiffen in the mould
#Text=.
#Text=
#Text=ORANGE JELLY.
#Text=This can be made with calf  '  s feet or without.
#Text=One quart of water will
#Text= require one ounce of isinglass, simmer the isinglass in the water,
#Text= and add the peel of one lemon and one orange; when the isinglass is
#Text= dissolved, add the juice of a lemon and six fine oranges; although the
#Text= quantity must vary according to the season for them, sweeten with half
#Text= a pound of white sugar; a Seville orange is added if there should not
#Text= be much flavor in the others.
#Text=Lemon jelly is made in the same way; the peel of a Seville orange and
#Text= of a lemon is used, with the juice of five lemons; rather more sugar
#Text= will be required with this jelly than with the former.
#Text=Punch jelly is made in the same way.
#Text=An equal quantity of brandy
#Text= and rum, with the juice of two or three lemons is mixed with the
#Text= isinglass, which is dissolved in one pint of water, the other pint of
#Text= liquid being made up by the lemon juice and spirits.
#Text=The essence of noyeau is reckoned to give an exquisite flavor, in this
#Text=the day-time, and using any of the emollients we have recommended for
#Text= softening and improving the skin.
#Text=CHAPTER V.
#Text=Dress.
#Text=In dress, simplicity should be preferred to magnificence: it is
#Text= surely more gratifying to be admired for a refined taste, than for an
#Text= elaborate and dazzling splendour;--the former always produces pleasing
#Text= impressions, while the latter generally only provokes criticism.
#Text=Too costly an attire forms a sort of fortification around a woman
#Text= which wards off the admiration she might otherwise attract.
#Text=The true
#Text= art of dress is to make it harmonize so perfectly with the style
#Text= of countenance and figure as to identify it, as it were, with the
#Text=character of the wearer.
#Text=All ornaments and trimmings should be adopted sparingly; trinkets and
#Text= jewellery should seldom appear to be worn merely for display; they
#Text= should be so selected and arranged as to seem necessary, either for
#Text= the proper adjustment of some part of the dress, or worn for the sake
#Text= of pleasing associations.
#Text=Fashion should never be followed too closely, still less should
#Text= a singularity of style be affected; the prevailing mode should be
#Text= modified and adapted to suit individual peculiarity.
#Text=The different
#Text= effect of colours and the various forms of dress should be duly
#Text= considered by every lady, as a refined taste in dress indicates a
#Text= correct judgment.
#Text=A short stout figure should avoid the loose flowing robes and ample
#Text= drapery suitable for tall slight women; while these again should
#Text= be cautious of adopting fashions which compress the figure, give
#Text= formality, or display angles.
#Text=The close-fitting corsage and tight
#Text= sleeve, becoming to the short, plump female, should be modified with
#Text=simple trimmings, to give fullness and width across the shoulders and
#Text= bust, and a rounded contour to the arms.
#Text=Flounces and tucks, which
#Text= rise high in the skirt, are not suitable to short persons; they cut
#Text= the figure and destroy symetry.
#Text=To tall women, on the contrary,
#Text= they add grace and dignity.
#Text=Dresses made half high are extremely
#Text= unbecoming; they should either be cut close up to the throat or low.
#Text=It is, however, in bad taste to wear them very low on the shoulders
#Text= and bosom: in youth, it gives evidence of the absence of that modesty
#Text= which is one of its greatest attractions; and in maturer years it is
#Text= the indication of a depraved coquetry, which checks the admiration it
#Text= invites.
#Text=It is always requisite for a lady to exert her own taste in the choice
#Text= of form, colour, and style, and not leave it to the fancy of her
#Text= dress-maker, as although the person she employs may be eminently
#Text= qualified for her profession, a lady who possesses any discernment can
#Text= best judge of what is suitable to her style of countenance and figure.
#Text=In dress there should be but one prevailing colour, to which all
#Text= others should be adapted, either by harmonising with it, or by
#Text=contrast; in the latter case the relieving color should be in small
#Text= quantity, or it would overpower the other in effect, as a general
#Text= rule, sombre negative colours show off a woman to the greatest
#Text= advantage, just as the beauties of a painting are enhanced by being
#Text= set in a dull frame; still, there are some occasions with which the
#Text= gayer tints accord better, and as propriety and fitness are matters of
#Text= high consideration, the woman of taste must be guided in the selection
#Text= of her apparel by the knowledge of the purport for which it is
#Text= intended, always endeavouring to fix on that shade of colour which
#Text= best becomes her complexion.
